labor_cost.title: Labor Cost Calculator
labor_cost.description: Calculate construction labor costs including wages, overtime, and overhead expenses.
labor_cost.regular_hours_tooltip: Total regular working hours per worker
labor_cost.hourly_rate_tooltip: Base pay rate per hour per worker
labor_cost.workers_count_tooltip: Total number of workers on the project
labor_cost.overhead_rate_tooltip: Additional costs like insurance, benefits, and equipment
labor_cost.formula: Total = (Hours × Rate × Workers) + (OT Hours × Rate × OT Multiplier × Workers) + Overhead
labor_cost.info_description: Accurate labor cost estimation is essential for project bidding and budget planning. Include overhead for insurance, benefits, and equipment costs.

errors.invalid_inputs: Please enter valid hours and hourly rate
errors.positive_values: Hours and rate must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_workers: Number of workers must be at least 1
errors.invalid_overhead: Overhead rate must be between 0 and 100
errors.invalid_multiplier: Overtime multiplier must be at least 1

howItWorks.title: How the Labor Cost Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total = (Regular Hours × Rate × Workers) + (OT Hours × Rate × Multiplier × Workers) + Overhead
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator computes total labor costs by combining regular wages, overtime pay with multipliers, and overhead expenses like insurance and benefits.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter regular working hours per worker

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Adjust overtime multiplier and overhead rate

useCases.title: Project Bidding
useCases.description: Calculate accurate labor costs for competitive construction bids and proposals.

useCases.title: Payroll Planning
useCases.description: Estimate weekly or monthly labor expenses for workforce management.

useCases.title: Cost Analysis
useCases.description: Compare labor costs across different crew sizes and work schedules.

useCases.title: Budget Forecasting
useCases.description: Project total labor expenses for multi-week construction projects.

seoTips: Include 15-30% overhead for insurance, benefits, taxes, and equipment
Factor in productivity rates - workers don't produce 100% of paid hours
Account for learning curves on complex or new types of work
Consider travel time and mobilization costs for remote job sites
Track actual hours vs estimated to improve future bidding accuracy

commonMistakes.solution: Always add 15-30% for insurance, taxes, benefits, and equipment
Plan for realistic schedules - construction often requires overtime
Account for breaks, weather delays, and non-productive time
Add foreman/supervisor costs at higher rates for proper oversight

faqs.question: What is a typical overhead rate for construction labor?
faqs.answer: Construction overhead typically ranges from 15-30% and includes worker's compensation insurance, liability insurance, payroll taxes, benefits, and equipment costs.

faqs.question: How do I calculate labor cost per square foot?
faqs.answer: Divide total labor cost by project square footage. This helps compare costs across projects and improve future estimates.

faqs.question: What is the standard overtime multiplier?
faqs.answer: Most jurisdictions require 1.5x (time-and-a-half) for hours over 40 per week. Some union contracts or holiday work may require 2x (double time).

faqs.question: How many labor hours per square foot for construction?
faqs.answer: This varies widely: residential framing averages 0.5-1 hour/sq ft, finish work 1-2 hours/sq ft, and complete home construction 10-15 hours/sq ft.

faqs.question: Should I include benefits in the hourly rate?
faqs.answer: You can either include benefits in the hourly rate or add them to overhead. Be consistent with your method to ensure accurate total costs.

material_cost.title: Material Cost Calculator
material_cost.description: Calculate total building material costs with tax for construction projects.
material_cost.tax_rate_tooltip: Sales tax or VAT percentage to apply
material_cost.formula: Total = Σ(Quantity × Unit Price) + Tax. Tax is calculated on the subtotal of all items.
material_cost.info_description: Track and estimate material costs for accurate project budgeting. Add multiple items with quantities and unit prices to calculate total expenses.

errors.no_materials: Please add at least one material with quantity and price
errors.invalid_tax: Tax rate must be between 0 and 100

howItWorks.title: How the Material Cost Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator helps you track all material expenses by adding individual items with quantities and unit prices. It automatically calculates subtotals, applies tax rates, and provides a comprehensive cost breakdown.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select your local currency for accurate pricing

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Add each material item with name, quantity, and unit price

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Continue adding items until all materials are listed

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Set the applicable tax rate (VAT/sales tax)

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Review the total cost breakdown for budgeting

useCases.title: Client Quotations
useCases.description: Generate itemized material costs for transparent client proposals.

seoTips: Always get quotes from multiple suppliers before finalizing material costs
Include delivery charges in your unit prices for accurate totals
Factor in price fluctuations for materials like lumber and steel
Keep records of actual costs vs estimates to improve future bidding accuracy
Consider bulk discounts when ordering large quantities

commonMistakes.solution: Include delivery charges in unit prices or add as a separate line item
Lock in prices with suppliers or add 5-10% contingency for volatile materials
Create comprehensive checklists including fasteners, adhesives, and consumables
Verify current tax rates and which items are taxable in your jurisdiction

faqs.question: How do I estimate material costs for a construction project?
faqs.answer: Start with accurate quantity takeoffs from plans, get current prices from suppliers, add waste factors, and include tax and delivery. This calculator helps organize all these costs.

faqs.question: What percentage should I add for material waste?
faqs.answer: Typically add 5-10% for waste on most materials. Complex installations with many cuts may require 15%. This should be added to quantities before calculating costs.

faqs.question: Should I include labor in material cost estimates?
faqs.answer: Material costs should be separate from labor. Use our Labor Cost Calculator for workforce expenses and combine both for total project cost.

faqs.question: How do I handle material price increases mid-project?
faqs.answer: Include escalation clauses in contracts, lock in prices with purchase orders, or add contingency funds (5-10%) to your estimates.

faqs.question: What materials typically have the most price volatility?
faqs.answer: Lumber, steel, copper, and fuel-dependent products like asphalt experience significant price swings. Get firm quotes and act quickly for these materials.

constructionCost.title: Construction Cost Calculator
constructionCost.description: Calculate total construction costs including materials, labor, permits, and contingency.
constructionCost.unit_tooltip: Select square feet or square meters
constructionCost.construction_type_tooltip: Type of construction affects cost per square foot
constructionCost.formula: Total = (Area × Cost per Sqft) + Permits + Contingency
constructionCost.info_description: Construction costs vary significantly by location, materials, and specifications. This calculator provides estimates based on typical cost ranges.

errors.positive_values: Area must be greater than zero

howItWorks.title: How the Construction Cost Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Cost = (Area × Cost per SF) × (1 + Contingency)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates total construction costs based on project area and construction type. It breaks down costs into materials, labor, permits, and includes contingency for unexpected expenses.

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select construction type and quality level

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Choose items to include in estimate

seoTips: Always include 10-20% contingency for unexpected costs
Material costs are typically 40-50% of total construction cost
Labor costs vary significantly by region - get local quotes
Permits and fees can add 1-5% to total project cost
Get multiple contractor bids to ensure competitive pricing

commonMistakes.solution: Always include 15-20% contingency for unforeseen issues
Research local permit fees - can be substantial in some areas
Include costs for clearing, grading, and utility connections
Allowances for fixtures, finishes, and appliances vary greatly

faqs.question: What is the average cost per square foot to build a house?
faqs.answer: Basic construction: $100-150/sqft, standard: $150-250/sqft, premium: $250-400+/sqft. Costs vary significantly by location and specifications.

faqs.question: What percentage of construction cost is labor?
faqs.answer: Labor typically accounts for 35-45% of total construction costs. This varies by project complexity and local labor rates.

faqs.question: How much should I budget for contingency?
faqs.answer: Budget 10-15% contingency for new construction, 15-20% for renovations where hidden issues may emerge.

faqs.question: What is not included in cost per square foot?
faqs.answer: Often excludes land, permits, architectural fees, landscaping, driveways, and some finishes. Clarify inclusions with contractors.

faqs.question: How do I reduce construction costs?
faqs.answer: Simple designs, standard materials, competitive bidding, value engineering, and acting as your own general contractor can reduce costs.
